Every year, Google looks back at our online queries and compiles a list of the top searches.
And for 2015, the top rank goes to former NBA player and reality TV star Lamar Odom.
Caitlyn Jenner was also right up there at the top along with the Paris terrorist attacks, ""Jurassic Park"" and that blue or gold dress, whatever it was.
Joining us now is Simon Rogers.
He's the data editor at Google News Lab, which put together all of this information.
Welcome to the show, Simon.
Hi, thanks for having me.
So right off the bat, how would you characterize the big trends in search this year?
Are there trends?

It's been a really interesting year because normally you might expect the big searches are going to be the kind of things that - I guess the kind of fluffier end of the news cycle, things that are entertainment or sports or whatever.
But actually, what we've seen are kind of real hard news stories coming top in a lot of the kind of categories that we've been looking at this year, things like the Paris attacks.
There were nearly a billion searches around the Paris attacks in the days around those events.

Those huge news stories, like the refugee crisis and even the Chinese stock market kind of crashing - all those stories have really generated a lot of kind of search interest over the year as well as ""Jurassic World"" or Caitlyn Jenner or Lamar Odom.
If you dig into the specifics of one event like the Paris attacks...
Yeah.
Is there anything you can figure out about how a search history informs how news travels from place to place or person to person?
The first attacks were around 18 minutes past 9, Paris time.
And within a few moments of that, as news started to spread on social media, people started searching for it as well.
And you could really see, within minutes, people are searching in Berlin, London, even in New York.
Within about 10 minutes of those events happening, people were starting to search in New York.
It's a fascinating glimpse.
Before there's a proper news report out there, before, you know, people really know what's going on, they're desperate to find out that information.
And so it's just speculative.
That's just people worrying about where they live.
